results.title: The Cape crusade (A)
results.creator_credit: Helen Grasswill and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Noel Pearson, Aboriginal lawyer and Cape York adviser, and his brother Gerhardt Pearson, Cape York leader, together and along with several key business people, philanthropists and the corporate world are attempting to change the social disintegration within the Cape York Aboriginal communities. This program explores the establishment of the Indigenous Enterprise Partnerships, a concept and strategy initiated by Noel Pearson, comprising of four private business entities - Westpac, Myer Foundation, Boston Consultancy and Bodyshop - and other leaders in the business world, along with Aboriginal leaders to provide employment and education to the remote indigenous communities and instigate social change especially amongst the younger generation. Disillusioned with Government bureaucracy and the welfare system, Noel and Gerhardt are committed to change, believing that to overcome the unemployment, alcoholism, gambling, illicit drug use, family violence and child abuse, change has to come from within the Aboriginal community itself. “Australian story” presents some of the early successes resulting from the partnership and includes interviews with Ann Sherry (Westpac), Colin Carter (Boston Consultancy), Noel Pearson and Gerhardt Pearson. Hosted by Caroline Jones.

results.title: Australian Story: Man For All Seasons: Wayne Bennett
results.creator_credit: Vanessa Gorman and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
This is Wayne Bennett’s story, a story of successes and failures, family, good times, challenging times, but most of all, about his passion for the Brisbane Broncos and helping them win more Grand Finals in his 20 years of coaching than any other club in Australian rugby league history. Introduced by Caroline Jones.
Broadcast on ABC TV on 6 May 1999. Reporters/producers include Ben Cheshire, Carolyn Davies, Brigid Donovan, Helen Grasswill, John Millard, Wendy Page.

results.title: Wives' tales
results.creator_credit: Claire Forster and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
280 families were affected by the deployment of the 7th and 8th battalion with INTERFET (UN Sanctioned International Force in East Timor). For the women and families left behind, there was a pressing need for group support. Shying away from a tag such as “the army wives club,” Patti-Jane Gould established the P.I.T. crew - Partners In Timor. The women of this support network speak candidly of the impact their partners departure has had on them and their children, how it feels to say goodbye, their fears, and how they adjust when life returns to “normal.” Army personnel share their fears and thoughts too and how their lives have changed since Timor. Finally, we share an emotional reunion on the docks. Introduced by Lieutenant General Peter Cosgrove.

results.title: A Track winding back (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
This documentary is based on a true story written by school teacher Carolyn Landon about bushman, Daryl Tonkin and his life and memories of Jackson’s Track in West Gippsland, Victoria. It is a story of love and tragedy, of an Aboriginal community living and working harmoniously with white people in the timber industry in the forest area of Jackson’s Track established by Daryl and his brother Harry during the 1930s. It tells of Daryl’s feud with his family when he decided to live with an Aboriginal woman, the dramatic kidnapping of this woman by his brother, Daryl’s life with the Aboriginal community and the eventual bull-dozing of the camp in the 1960s to appease local Christian groups resulting in the break-up and dispersal of the almost 100 people living at the camp. Daryl talks of himself as being at one with the Aboriginal way of life, a true bushman, who saw his life neither primitive nor of poverty and hardship, but as being his preferred way of life. Includes interviews with two of his nine children, re-enactments, stills and archival footage, and excerpts from the film “Rose against the odds”. Contains some b&w images.

results.title: Bridge over Myall Creek (A)
results.creator_credit: Caitlin Shea, Margaret Parker, Wendy Page, John Millard, Helen Gasswill, Vanessa Gorman, Brigid Donovan, Samantha Butler and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Caroline Jones introduces this episode of “Australian story” which looks at personal reconciliation in action as demonstrated by the relationship between Sue Blacklock and Beulah Adams, descendants of victim and perpetrator in the 1838 Myall Creek massacre. Researching into her family history, Beulah Adams discovered her great uncle was one of the perpetrators in a massacre that saw 28 Aborigines killed. Beulah talks candidly about her reaction to the news, and her experience at meeting Sue Blacklock, descendant of one of the two survivors at a conference on reconciliation convened by Reverend John Brown. Another descendant of the perpetrators, Des Blake, talks about his experience at attending the memorial’s opening at Myall Creek in 2002, and how the experience has changed his life since then.

results.title: [Agnotes Advertisement: 1]
results.brief_description:
Victoria’s Department of Agriculture (now Agriculture Victoria) produced Agnotes, a series of reference material for the industry with the aim to disseminate expert advise for best agricultural practices.

This advertisement was designed to increase the uptake of the Agnotes by farmers. It is one of many commercials produced for the Department of Agriculture.

results.title: The Voice of Agriculture
results.creator_credit: Tony Doogood and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, this short film is an advertisement for the radio broadcast “The Voice of Agriculture”. Typical of the (now outdated) representation of gender roles of the time, the film opens with a domestic scene in which the mother of the family is making dinner while her husband discusses farm work. The farmer, who is having trouble with his sheep, calls on professional help from a veterinarian at the Department of Agriculture, who informs him about the radio program “The Voice of Agriculture”, which is designed to help farmers like him. The film then shows the behind-the-scenes production of the broadcast, including voice actors, radio technicians and vintage wireless sets.

results.title: Vine grafting
results.brief_description: Deals with several methods of cutting and grafting for production of Phylloxera resistant grapevine canes in the north of Victoria. The film shows the activities of the staff of the Rutherglen research station inside the sheds and in the field, planting and propagating the canes.
results.description: Deals with several methods of cutting and grafting for production of Phylloxera resistant grapevine canes in the north of Victoria. The film shows the activities of the staff of the Rutherglen research station inside the sheds and in the field, planting and propagating the canes.

results.title: Vegetable Growing at Home
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film is a government-produced educational film designed to encourage viewers to grow their own vegetables at home during the Second World War. Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, the film features a suburban couple who receive a brochure in the mail called ‘Wartime Vegetable Growing at Home’. The educational intent of the film is interspersed with comic scenes predicated on the (now outdated) gender roles of the time as the domestic housewife, Mary, sabotages her husband’s plans to play golf and convinces him to start a vegetable garden. With the assistance of the girl next door, a student at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the hapless husband begins transforming his patch of grass and stops sulking. Moving to an instructional section filmed at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the film’s narrator explains how to dig a patch, turn over and rake the soil, and plant seeds, with the process performed by another expert female gardener (despite clearly being a skilled professional, the narrator mocks her for being a woman). The gardener then demonstrates how to thin out young plants, cultivate the soil and deal with pests, with occasional interludes back to the comic scenes of the domestic couple. Finally, the film shows the rewards of growing your own vegetables, with a bountiful harvest from the garden.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
